%text A lot of people mistakenly assume that \[ \sin^{-1}x = \dfrac{1}{\sin x} \]. It is not.
\underline\text{$\sin^{-1} x, \cos^{-1}x$ etc are angles !} By definition, \[ \sin\theta = x \implies \sin^{-1} x=\theta \] Same goes for $\cos^{-1}x$ or $\tan^{-1}x$.
$\theta$ in the above equation belongs to what is called the \underline\text{principal range}. It is the \underline\text{smallest range of angles} that will give all possible values for a trigonometric function. These are summarized below.
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Function} & x \in & \text{Principal Range} \\ \hline y = \sin^{-1}x & [-1,1] & \left[ -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2} \right] \\ \hline y = \cos^{-1} x & [-1,1] & [0,\pi] \\ \hline y = \tan^{-1} x & \mathbb{R} & \left( -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2} \right) \\ \hline y = \csc^{-1}x & \mathbb{R}-(-1,1) & \left[ -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2} \right] - \lbrace 0\rbrace \\ \hline y = \sec^{-1}x & \mathbb{R}-(-1,1) & \left[ 0,\pi \right] - \lbrace \frac\pi{2}\rbrace \\ \hline y = \cot^{-1} x & \mathbb{R} & (0,\pi) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
